arXiv:2410.04264v1 [stat.ML] 05 Oct 2024

Visualising Feature Learning in Deep Neural Networks by Diagonalizing the Forward Feature Map

\nameYoonsoo Nam \emailyoonsoo.nam@physics.ox.ac.uk
\addrDepartment of Theoretical Physics
University of Oxford
\nameChris Mingard \emailchristopher.mingard@queens.ox.ac.uk
\addrDepartment of Theoretical Physics/Department of Chemistry
University of Oxford
\nameSeok Hyeong Lee \emaillshyeong@snu.ac.kr
\addrCenter for Quantum Structures in Modules and Spaces
Seoul National University
\nameSoufiane Hayou \emailhayou@berkeley.edu
\addrSimons Institute
UC Berkeley
\nameArd Louis \emailard.louis@physics.ox.ac.uk
\addrDepartment of Theoretical Physics
University of Oxford
Abstract

Deep neural networks (DNNs) exhibit a remarkable ability to automatically learn data representations, finding appropriate features without human input. Here we present a method for analysing feature learning by decomposing DNNs into 1) a forward feature-map Î¦:Ï‡â†’â„p:Î¦â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ‘\Phi:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Î¦ : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that maps the input dataspace Ï‡ğœ’\textstyle\chiitalic_Ï‡ to the pğ‘pitalic_p post-activations of the penultimate layer, and 2) a final linear layer that classifies the data. We diagonalize Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ with respect to the gradient descent operator and track feature learning by measuring how the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues of Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ change during training. Across many popular architectures and classification datasets, we find that DNNs converge, after just a few epochs, to a minimal feature (MF) regime dominated by a number of eigenfunctions equal to the number of classes. This behaviour resembles the neural collapse phenomenon studied at longer training times. For other DNN-data combinations, such as a fully connected network on CIFAR10, we find an extended feature (EF) regime where significantly more features are used. Optimal generalisation performance upon hyperparameter tuning typically coincides with the MF regime, but we also find examples of poor performance within the MF regime. Finally, we recast the phenomenon of neural collapse into a kernel picture which can be extended to broader tasks such as regression.

1 Introduction

The pioneers of deep learning designed deep neural networks (DNNs) with layer-wise modules, crafted to automatically learn representations of the raw data that can easily be separated with a relatively small final linear layer [LeCun et al., 2015; Schmidhuber, 2015; Bengio et al., 2013]. In Figure 1(a) we schematically depict this basic architecture, which is shared by most DNNs. DNNs are characterised by their feature maps Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦, which create a non-linear transformation from the data space Ï‡ğœ’\chiitalic_Ï‡ into a representation â„psuperscriptâ„ğ‘\mathbb{R}^{p}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: which are the post-activations of the penultimate layer. These, in turn, serve as the inputs (or features) for the final linear layer. Most DNNs share this abstract structure and differ mainly in how they create their feature maps. Examples of feature maps include a series of fully-connected layers, as in an FCN, a combination of convolutional and pooling layers, as in a CNN [LeCun et al., 1989], including very deep CNNs such as a VGG [Simonyan and Zisserman, 2014], or a combination of convolutional layers and skip connections, as in a ResNet [He et al., 2016], or an encoder-decoder architecture, as in the original transformers [Vaswani et al., 2017], and many more. Within this simple schema, feature learning can be defined as any changes in the feature map Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ due to the training process.

It is also possible to fix the feature map â€“ by randomly selecting its parameters â€“ and to only learn the final layer weights. Since only the last layer can be trained, such a network is typically much less expressive than a standard DNN of the same width. In order to reach zero training error, the final layer for a frozen feature map must be significantly wider than what is typical of DNNs in modern practice. For example, in Figure 1(b) we show that even for the relatively simple task of separating the training set of the MINST image dataset, a CNN with fixed random convolutional layers needs a width of at least p=1000ğ‘1000p=1000italic_p = 1000 to obtain zero training error. For more complex datasets, much wider layers are needed to achieve zero training error for frozen feature maps. For CIFAR10, for example, widths on the order of pâ‰ˆnğ‘ğ‘›p\approx nitalic_p â‰ˆ italic_n are needed to achieve zero training error for a frozen feature map (see Section A). By contrast, if the hidden layers are allowed to change under training, i.e. if feature-learning is allowed, then a width of just p=20ğ‘20p=20italic_p = 20 is sufficient to achieve zero training error for MNIST, and very modest final layers can achieve this for more complex datasets. In other words, the practice of choosing a relatively narrow final layer with pâ‰ªnmuch-less-thanğ‘ğ‘›p\ll nitalic_p â‰ª italic_n and training to zero-training error or small loss means the DNN must learn new representations in the hidden layers that are relatively easy to linearly separate by the final layer.

The ability of DNNs to automatically feature learn has long been thought to play a key role in the impressive performance of DNNs over a wide range of tasks [Bengio et al., 2013; LeCun et al., 2015; Schmidhuber, 2015; Simonyan and Zisserman, 2014; Goodfellow et al., 2014; He et al., 2016; Devlin et al., 2018]. On the other hand, more recent work investigating the infinite width limits of DNNs, where they can reduce to a Gaussian process (NNGP) [Neal, 1994; Lee et al., 2018; Matthews et al., 2018] or a Neural Tangent Kernel (NTK) [Jacot et al., 2018] has also demonstrated impressive performance on some key model tasks [Lee et al., 2020; Arora et al., 2019]. Since these are limits where no feature learning occurs, this good performance complicates the hypothesis that feature learning is a necessary characteristic of DNNs. The theoretical simplifications that these infinite width limits bring has stimulated a great deal of research see e.g. [Allen-Zhu and Li, 2019; Daniely and Malach, 2020; Refinetti et al., 2021; Lee et al., 2020; Arora et al., 2019; Ba et al., 2022; Atanasov et al., 2021; Damian et al., 2022; Jacot et al., 2022; Malach et al., 2021; Mousavi-Hosseini et al., 2022; Daniel A. Roberts, 2021; Mei et al., 2018; Rotskoff and Vanden-Eijnden, 2018; Chizat et al., 2019; Geiger et al., 2020, 2021; Yang and Hu, 2021; Yang et al., 2021; Naveh and Ringel, 2021; Bordelon and Pehlevan, 2022, 2023; Vyas et al., 2022; Petrini et al., 2023; Seroussi et al., 2023; Vyas et al., 2023]. Nevertheless, although state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance for most tasks is still achieved by a suitably optimised finite-width DNN where feature learning must occur in order to reach low training errors, the precise role that feature learning plays in optimising the generalisation performance of DNNs remains an open question.

While to 1st order, the idea that changes in the feature map Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ under training signal feature learning is widely shared, there are many different proposals in the literature for how to measure and quantify this phenomenon. These include direct visualization of hidden layer representations [Zeiler and Fergus, 2014; Girshick et al., 2014; Molnar, 2020], or measuring changes to certain kernels that should be constant without feature learning such as the NTK [Jacot et al., 2018; Atanasov et al., 2021] and the forward feature kernel [Yang and Hu, 2021; Canatar and Pehlevan, 2022]. The learned representations, or features, are exploited in algorithms such as Google Deep Dream [Mordvintsev et al., 2015], style transfer [Jing et al., 2019], and transfer learning more broadly [Weiss et al., 2016]. Sometimes, these features are human-interpretable, as is thought to be the case for CNN filters (see [Goodfellow et al., 2016], for example).

We begin by considering the simpler case of linear models, where features are mathematically well-defined as the basis functions in which one expands the learned function. To be more precise, any datapoint of an input dataspace, xâˆˆÏ‡ğ‘¥ğœ’x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_x âˆˆ italic_Ï‡ can be mapped to a vector or tensor (e.g. vectors of tokens) via a feature map Î¦:Ï‡â†’â„p:Î¦â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ‘\Phi:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Î¦ : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, a linear model can be defined with respect to the parameters Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ as:

fâ¢(x)=âˆ‘k=1pÎ¸kâ¢Î¦kâ¢(x),xâˆ¼q,Î¦:Ï‡â†’â„p,:formulae-sequenceğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¥similar-toğ‘¥ğ‘Î¦â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ‘f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\theta_{k}\Phi_{k}(x),\quad\quad x\sim q,\quad\Phi:{% \mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p},italic_f ( italic_x ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , italic_x âˆ¼ italic_q , roman_Î¦ : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (1)

where qğ‘qitalic_q is the true distribution of the data, pğ‘pitalic_p is the number of parameters of the linear model, and Î¦kâ¢(x)subscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¥\Phi_{k}(x)roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) is the ktâ¢hsuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„k^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry of the feature vector. Since the features Î¦kâ¢(x)subscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¥\Phi_{k}(x)roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) are fixed for linear models, the training task simply means learning the coefficients Î¸ksubscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta_{k}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Next, we note that the linear formalism of Equation 1 can also be used to describe a snapshot of a DNN at a given time during the training process where Î¸ksubscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta_{k}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the parameters of the last layer (for simplicity we have ignored bias terms), and Î¦â¢(x)Î¦ğ‘¥\Phi(x)roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) is its feature-map at that time, which outputs the post-activations of the penultimate layer of the DNN. The difference with the linear model is that a DNN can go beyond merely learning the coefficients Î¸ksubscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta_{k}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and change the features Î¦kâ¢(x)subscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¥\Phi_{k}(x)roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) upon further training, as illustrated, for example, in Figure 2.

Since DNNs are typically trained with stochastic gradient descent (SGD), we diagonalize the feature map Î¦â¢(x)Î¦ğ‘¥\Phi(x)roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) at any given time-step with respect to the gradient descent (GD) operator, and define features at each time-step in terms of the eigenfunctions of this operator. We visualise and quantify feature learning by monitoring changes to projection operators of the eigenfunctions onto the target function and the learned function, and changes to the eigenvalue spectrum under training. Formal definitions and further details of these measures are given in the next section.

There are, of course, many other ways to analyse how DNNs learn features besides the schema depicted in Figure 1(a). In particular, this method ignores the details of how the features evolve in earlier layers (see however Section D) that make up the feature map. However, defining features in terms of the forward-feature map, as we do here, abounds in the literature. Moreover, our measures are computationally relatively efficient to calculate, allowing us to empirically explore feature learning from initialization to convergence for a set of popular DNN architectures (FCN, CNN, ResNet18, and VGG) and image datasets (MNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR100), and for different hyperparameters.

1.1 Our contributions

  1. 1.

    We introduce a computationally efficient method for monitoring feature learning in DNNs, based on projections of eigenfunctions of the forward feature-map Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ on the target function and the learned function, as well as measures of the effective dimension of the eigenvalue distribution (Section 2).

  2. 2.

    We distinguish coefficient learning, when no feature learning occurs and only final layer parameters are learned, from a minimal feature (MF) regime (where the number of features describing the learned function equals the number of classes) and an extended feature (EF) learning regime that covers behaviour between the two extremes (Section 2).

  3. 3.

    We find that upon increasing the training set size nğ‘›nitalic_n, feature learning can change from the EF regime to the MF regime. Moreover, the scaling exponent of the test error and loss with training set size nğ‘›nitalic_n increases upon the emergence of the MF regime from the EF regime (Section 3.1).

  4. 4.

    We show that the MF regime can arise early in training, even after just a few epochs (Section 3.2).

  5. 5.

    We find that multiplying the output by a constant, as is done to enter the so-called lazy regimeâ€”where DNN training can be described by a linear model [Chizat et al., 2019; Geiger et al., 2020; Bordelon and Pehlevan, 2022; Petrini et al., 2023]â€”shifts feature learning from the MF regime to the EF regime for typical DNN widths where pâ‰ªnmuch-less-thanğ‘ğ‘›p\ll nitalic_p â‰ª italic_n. To completely eliminate feature learning, DNNs must be much wider, with pâ‰³ngreater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘ğ‘›p\gtrsim nitalic_p â‰³ italic_n for more complex datasets (Section 3.3).

  6. 6.

    Our measures allow us to visualise and analyse the quality of features in the context of transfer learning (Section 3.4)

  7. 7.

    We find that the MF regime can be obtained even on random data, suggesting that its origin lies in the training dynamics (Section 4.1).

  8. 8.

    Upon hyperparameter tuning, we find that typically, but not always, a tighter MF regime gives better performance (Section 4.2).

  9. 9.

    An important body of recent work has shown that for balanced classification problems, the penultimate layer post-activations can collapse to a symmetric and geometrically simple minimal representation, typically upon overtraining well past zero training error. This phenomenon has been called neural collapse (NC) [Papyan et al., 2020; Han et al., 2021] and is closely related to our MF regime. We introduce a minimum projection operator with which we can analyse the phenomenon of NC within a kernel picture. This formalism allows us to extend the concept of NC to regression (Section 5).

2 Definitions and methodology

In this section, we define the series of measures we will use to quantify and visualise feature learning, and explain how to calculate them efficiently. Then, we illustrate how our measures work using two simple examples, a toy FCN on a 1-dimensional function, where the full eigenfunctions can be visualised, and a CNN on MNIST with large enough pğ‘pitalic_p so that both coefficient learning and SGD on all layers can reach zero training error.

2.1 Feature learning and coefficient learning

As illustrated in Figure 1(a), a DNN can be decomposed into a forward feature map Î¦:Ï‡â†’â„p:Î¦â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ‘\Phi:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Î¦ : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that maps the raw data (e.g. an image) to a pğ‘pitalic_p-dimensional vector, and a final linear layer of finite width pğ‘pitalic_p. We will assume the data xâˆˆÏ‡ğ‘¥ğœ’x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_x âˆˆ italic_Ï‡ are sampled from a true distribution qğ‘qitalic_q (i.e. xâˆ¼qsimilar-toğ‘¥ğ‘x\sim qitalic_x âˆ¼ italic_q). From this simple decomposition it follows that feature learning occurs when the forward feature map changes. More formally:

Definition 1 (Feature learning).

A DNN is said to undergo feature learning if at any time tğ‘¡titalic_t during training, Î¦(t):Ï‡â†’â„p:subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ‘\Phi_{(t)}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt% }{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT differs from the forward feature map Î¦(0)subscriptÎ¦0\Phi_{(0)}roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at initialization (t=0ğ‘¡0t=0italic_t = 0). The feature maps are considered distinct if there exists an xâˆˆÏ‡ğ‘¥ğœ’x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_x âˆˆ italic_Ï‡ such that Î¦(0)â¢(x)â‰ Î¦(t)â¢(x)subscriptÎ¦0ğ‘¥subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡ğ‘¥\Phi_{(0)}(x)\neq\Phi_{(t)}(x)roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) â‰  roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ).

From this definition, it follows that if the feature map Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ remains fixed and does not change during training, no feature learning takes place. In this case, only the coefficients (parameters) of the final linear layer are adjusted during training, a scenario we define as follows:

Definition 2 (Coefficient Learning).

A DNN is said to undergo coefficient learning if the forward feature map Î¦(t):Ï‡â†’â„p:subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ‘\Phi_{(t)}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt% }{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT remains fixed at all times tğ‘¡titalic_t during training such that âˆ€xâˆˆÏ‡for-allğ‘¥ğœ’\forall x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0% pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{% $\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}âˆ€ italic_x âˆˆ italic_Ï‡, Î¦(0)â¢(x)=Î¦(t)â¢(x)subscriptÎ¦0ğ‘¥subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡ğ‘¥\Phi_{(0)}(x)=\Phi_{(t)}(x)roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ). In this case, no feature learning occurs, and only the parameters (coefficients) of the final linear layer of the DNN are updated during training.

Coefficient learning occurs in the much-studied case of random features, where the parameters of Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ are set by a random sample over a distribution, and then not allowed to change under training. In the infinite width limit, it is equivalent to taking a sample from the NNGP [Radhakrishnan, 2022].

2.2 Features from the eigenfunctions of forward feature map

To define features, we begin by calculating the eigenfunctions ek:Ï‡â†’â„:subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜â†’ğœ’â„e_{k}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R and eigenvalues ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ using a standard analysis from the kernel literature [Smola and SchÃ¶lkopf, 1998; Williams and Rasmussen, 2006] in terms of the integral operator T:L2â¢(Ï‡)â†’L2â¢(Ï‡):ğ‘‡â†’superscriptğ¿2ğœ’superscriptğ¿2ğœ’T:L^{2}({\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}})\rightarrow L^{2}({\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}})italic_T : italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï‡ ) â†’ italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï‡ ):

Tâ¢[f]â¢(xâ€²):=âˆ«Ï‡Î¦â¢(x)Tâ¢Î¦â¢(xâ€²)â¢fâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘x,Tâ¢[ek]=Ïkâ¢ek,formulae-sequenceassignğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â€²subscriptğœ’Î¦superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡Î¦superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥ğ‘‡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜subscriptğœŒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜T[f](x^{\prime}):=\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x)^{T}\Phi(x^{\prime})f(x)q(x% )dx,\quad\quad T[e_{k}]=\rho_{k}e_{k},italic_T [ italic_f ] ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) := âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x , italic_T [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (2)

where âŸ¨ei|ejâŸ©=Î´iâ¢jinner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–subscriptğ‘’ğ‘—subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—\braket{e_{i}}{e_{j}}=\delta_{ij}âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© = italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the bra-ket notation in âŸ¨â‹…|â‹…âŸ©inner-productâ‹…â‹…\braket{\cdot}{\cdot}âŸ¨ start_ARG â‹… end_ARG | start_ARG â‹… end_ARG âŸ© denotes the L2superscriptğ¿2L^{2}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT inner product defined on measure qğ‘qitalic_q (i.e. âŸ¨f|gâŸ©=âˆ«Ï‡fâ¢(x)â¢gâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xinner-productğ‘“ğ‘”subscriptğœ’ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥\braket{f}{g}=\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}f(x)g(x)q(x)dxâŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_g end_ARG âŸ© = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) italic_g ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x). The integral operator Tğ‘‡Titalic_T and its eigenfunctions [e1,e2,â€¦,ep]subscriptğ‘’1subscriptğ‘’2â€¦subscriptğ‘’ğ‘[e_{1},e_{2},\dots,e_{p}][ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] are of particular interest because Tğ‘‡Titalic_T diagonalizes the dynamics of the linear model trained with gradient descent (GD) and mean square error (MSE) loss111Technically, these equations are obtained under a continuous limit of gradient flow. For completeness, we provide a full derivation of the dynamics of linear models in Section E. Then the learning dynamics decompose into pğ‘pitalic_p independent dynamical equations, one for each eigenfunction:

fâ¢(x)=âˆ‘k=1pâŸ¨f|ekâŸ©â¢ekâ¢(x),âŸ¨f|ekâŸ©â¢(t)=âŸ¨fâˆ—|ekâŸ©â¢(1âˆ’eâˆ’Î·â¢Ïkâ¢t).formulae-sequenceğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘inner-productğ‘“subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥inner-productğ‘“subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡inner-productsuperscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘’ğœ‚subscriptğœŒğ‘˜ğ‘¡f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\braket{f}{e_{k}}e_{k}(x),\quad\quad\ \braket{f}{e_{k}}(t)=% \braket{f^{*}}{e_{k}}(1-e^{-\eta\rho_{k}t}).italic_f ( italic_x ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© ( italic_t ) = âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î· italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (3)

Here, we have assumed that all coefficients âŸ¨f|ekâŸ©inner-productğ‘“subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜\braket{f}{e_{k}}âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© are initialized to zero at t=0ğ‘¡0t=0italic_t = 0, and that the MSE loss is calculated with respect to a target function fâˆ—â¢(x)superscriptğ‘“ğ‘¥f^{*}(x)italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ). Note that for fixed Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦, the speed at which each coefficient âŸ¨f|ekâŸ©inner-productğ‘“subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜\braket{f}{e_{k}}âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© is learned depends on the eigenvalues ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· of the GD algorithm used. The larger the eigenvalue, the faster the coefficient is learned.

In the context of a DNN, the dynamics of Equation 3 describe what would happen if one were to fix at a given time tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the hidden layers, and thus the feature map Î¦(tâ€²)â¢(x)subscriptÎ¦superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘¥\Phi_{(t^{\prime})}(x)roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) (with eigenfunctions ekâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜â€²e_{k}^{\prime}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), and subsequently train only the final layer. This picture is equivalent to interpreting the feature map at t=tâ€²ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²t=t^{\prime}italic_t = italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the one fixed at initialization so that there is no feature learning, and the DNN only learns the coefficients âŸ¨fâˆ—|ekâ€²âŸ©inner-productsuperscriptğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜â€²\braket{f^{*}}{e_{k}^{\prime}}âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© (although we might hope Î¦(tâ€²)â¢(x)subscriptÎ¦superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘¥\Phi_{(t^{\prime})}(x)roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) is better than Î¦(t)â¢(x)subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡ğ‘¥\Phi_{(t)}(x)roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x )). Indeed, Equation 3 describes the full dynamics of learning the coefficients for GD with MSE loss under the coefficient learning regime from Definition 2.

DNNs are not normally trained with a fixed feature map. Indeed, since DNNs are non-linear, they can change their feature maps by parameter updates in the intermediate layers, making Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦, and therefore also the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues defined in Equation 2, time-dependent. This suggests we can monitor (non-linear) feature learning by analysing changes in the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions defined by the above procedure. Within this picture, it is therefore natural to formally define our features as follows:

Definition 3 (Features).

Given the true data distribution qğ‘qitalic_q and a forward feature map Î¦:Ï‡â†’â„p:Î¦â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ‘\Phi:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Î¦ : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT mapping data to the input of the last layer of DNN, the pğ‘pitalic_p eigenfunctions [e1,e2â¢â€¦â¢ep]subscriptğ‘’1subscriptğ‘’2â€¦subscriptğ‘’ğ‘[e_{1},e_{2}\dots e_{p}][ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â€¦ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] of the feature map are obtained by diagonalizing the integral operator Tğ‘‡Titalic_T in Equation 2. These eigenfunctions are indexed in descending order according to their corresponding eigenvalues ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The ktâ¢hsuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„k^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT feature is defined as a scalar-valued function on the input probability space, denoted as ekâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) for xâˆ¼qsimilar-toğ‘¥ğ‘x\sim qitalic_x âˆ¼ italic_q. Since xğ‘¥xitalic_x is normally chosen at random, the features are scalar random variables.

An intuitive way of thinking about this definition of the ktâ¢hsuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„k^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT feature is as a linear combination of the pğ‘pitalic_p entries of the input to the final layer, chosen such that it reflects the natural direction of the data after the transform via the feature-map Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦, similar in spirit to how SVD finds the â€œnatural directionâ€ of the matrix. Variations of the definition above are also possible, see Section B.

2.3 Measuring feature learning by projecting onto the learned function and the target function

While using Definition 3 for features has certain practical advantages which we will explore further in this paper, the eigenfunctions (features) are typically hard to visualise directly for high-dimensional problems. To make progress in analysing and visualising feature learning, we will define measures based on projecting the eigenfunctions onto either the target function fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which describes the target function on all the data xâˆˆÏ‡ğ‘¥ğœ’x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_x âˆˆ italic_Ï‡, or else the learned function f^^ğ‘“\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG that the DNN expresses once training on a training set Stâ¢râˆˆÏ‡subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğœ’S_{tr}\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{% $\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_Ï‡ is complete.

Before defining our measures, we note that for the sake of simplicity, we considered DNNs with scalar output functions fğ‘“fitalic_f in the previous sections. For a balanced Cğ¶Citalic_C-way classification task, the target function is a vector function (i.e. fâˆ—:Ï‡â†’â„C:superscriptğ‘“â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ¶f^{*}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), and the dataspace Ï‡ğœ’\textstyle\chiitalic_Ï‡ can be partitioned into subspaces {A1,â‹¯,AC}subscriptğ´1â‹¯subscriptğ´ğ¶\{A_{1},\cdots,A_{C}\}{ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } by class. The components fiâˆ—:Ï‡â†’â„:subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘–â†’ğœ’â„f^{*}_{i}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}% {$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R for iâˆˆ[1,â‹¯,C]ğ‘–1â‹¯ğ¶i\in[1,\cdots,C]italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 , â‹¯ , italic_C ] of fâˆ—=[f1âˆ—,â‹¯,fCâˆ—]superscriptğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“1â‹¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ¶f^{*}=[f^{*}_{1},\cdots,f^{*}_{C}]italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] can be written down as:

fiâˆ—â¢(x)=ğŸAiâ¢(x)(Ai={x:xâ¢ is in class â¢i})superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscript1subscriptğ´ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ´ğ‘–conditional-setğ‘¥ğ‘¥ is in class ğ‘–f_{i}^{*}(x)=\mathbf{1}_{A_{i}}(x)\quad\quad(A_{i}=\{x:x\textrm{ is in class }% i\})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x : italic_x is in class italic_i } ) (4)

where ğŸAisubscript1subscriptğ´ğ‘–\mathbf{1}_{A_{i}}bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the indicator function for Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that because all the classes are mutually exclusive, we have

âŸ¨fiâˆ—|fjâˆ—âŸ©=âˆ«Ï‡fiâˆ—â¢(x)â¢fjâˆ—â¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘x=1Câ¢Î´iâ¢j,inner-productsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ’superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥1ğ¶subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—\braket{f^{*}_{i}}{f^{*}_{j}}=\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}f_{i}^{*}(x)f_% {j}^{*}(x)q(x)dx=\frac{1}{C}\delta_{ij},âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (5)

where the Câˆ’1superscriptğ¶1C^{-1}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the right-hand side comes from the probability measure for each class iğ‘–iitalic_i. Then it follows that at least Cğ¶Citalic_C orthogonal scalar output functions are needed to express fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We define the target function space â„‹âˆ—superscriptâ„‹\mathcal{H}^{*}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the function space spanned by [f1âˆ—,â‹¯,fCâˆ—]subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“1â‹¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ¶[f^{*}_{1},\cdots,f^{*}_{C}][ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ].

Given a C-class vector target function fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a projection operator Pâ„‹âˆ—:L2â¢(Ï‡)â†’L2â¢(Ï‡):subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptâ„‹â†’superscriptğ¿2ğœ’superscriptğ¿2ğœ’P_{\mathcal{H}^{*}}:L^{2}({\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}})\rightarrow L^{2}({\mathchoice{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi% $}}})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï‡ ) â†’ italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï‡ ) onto the target function space â„‹âˆ—superscriptâ„‹\mathcal{H}^{*}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we define the quality Qkâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜Q^{*}_{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of a feature eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows:

(6)

The range of Qkâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜Q^{*}_{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given by 0â‰¤Qkâˆ—â‰¤Câˆ’10subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜superscriptğ¶10\leq Q^{*}_{k}\leq C^{-1}0 â‰¤ italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We use the word quality because Qkâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜Q^{*}_{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measures how much eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overlaps with the Cğ¶Citalic_C dimensional target function space â„‹âˆ—superscriptâ„‹\mathcal{H}^{*}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The higher the quality the more of the target function is captured by the feature. We also define a cumulative measure of the quality of the first kğ‘˜kitalic_k eigenfunctions, ordered by the size of their eigenvalues:

Î âˆ—â¢(k):=âˆ‘j=1kQkâˆ—=âˆ‘j=1kâˆ‘i=1CâŸ¨ej|fiâˆ—âŸ©2.assignsuperscriptÎ ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¶superscriptinner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–2\Pi^{*}(k):=\sum_{j=1}^{k}Q^{*}_{k}=\sum_{j=1}^{k}\sum_{i=1}^{C}\braket{e_{j}}% {f_{i}^{*}}^{2}.roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) := âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (7)

We will call this measure the cumulative quality. Its range is given by 0â‰¤Î âˆ—â¢(k)â‰¤10superscriptÎ ğ‘˜10\leq\Pi^{*}(k)\leq 10 â‰¤ roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) â‰¤ 1. Assuming the fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are linearly independent, Î fâˆ—â¢(k)subscriptsuperscriptÎ ğ‘“ğ‘˜\Pi^{*}_{f}(k)roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k ) measures how much of the Cğ¶Citalic_C dimensional function space spanned by fğ‘“fitalic_f is captured by the first kğ‘˜kitalic_k eigenfunctions or features. Another way of expressing this concept is to say that Î âˆ—â¢(k)superscriptÎ ğ‘˜\Pi^{*}(k)roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) measures how well the first kğ‘˜kitalic_k eigenfunctions are aligned with fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For a DNN with a final layer width pğ‘pitalic_p, there are pğ‘pitalic_p features (eigenfunctions). We expect that total alignment or total quality of all the features, Î âˆ—â¢(p)superscriptÎ ğ‘\Pi^{*}(p)roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ), will typically increase under training. The highest possible total alignment/quality, when the DNN expresses the true-function fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is Î âˆ—â¢(p)=1superscriptÎ ğ‘1\Pi^{*}(p)=1roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) = 1. The minimum number of features for which Î âˆ—â¢(k)=1superscriptÎ ğ‘˜1\Pi^{*}(k)=1roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) = 1 can be attained is at k=Cğ‘˜ğ¶k=Citalic_k = italic_C, which would occur when the quality of Qksubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜Q_{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of each feature is at its maximum value of 1/C1ğ¶1/C1 / italic_C. Related cumulative measures of alignment/quality in the context of deep learning can be found for example in [Cristianini et al., 2001; Raghu et al., 2017; Canatar et al., 2021; Canatar and Pehlevan, 2022]. In particular, recent studies [Canatar et al., 2021; Jacot et al., 2020; Cui et al., 2021; Harzli et al., 2021; Simon et al., 2021] have linked better alignment at lower kğ‘˜kitalic_k to better generalization performance in overparameterized linear models. Due to the narrow final layer widths, the learning problem described here is underparameterized, but the idea that good generalisation correlates with large Î âˆ—â¢(p)superscriptÎ ğ‘\Pi^{*}(p)roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) should be robust.

Analogous measures to those above for the target function fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can also be defined for the vector function f^:Ï‡â†’â„C:^ğ‘“â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ¶\hat{f}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{C}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT expressed by the DNN after training, which we call the â€˜learned functionâ€™. The learned function space is given by â„‹^=sâ¢pâ¢aâ¢nâ¢{f^1,â‹¯,f^C}^â„‹ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›subscript^ğ‘“1â‹¯subscript^ğ‘“ğ¶\hat{\mathcal{H}}=span\{\hat{f}_{1},\cdots,\hat{f}_{C}\}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG = italic_s italic_p italic_a italic_n { over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Similarly, a projection operator Pâ„‹^subscriptğ‘ƒ^â„‹P_{\hat{\mathcal{H}}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT onto the learned function space can be defined as in Equation 6. This can then be used to define the utility Q^ksubscript^ğ‘„ğ‘˜\hat{Q}_{k}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the kğ‘˜kitalic_kth feature which measures how much the trained DNN uses that feature to express f^^ğ‘“\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG:

Q^k=âŸ¨ek|Pâ„‹^â¢[ek]âŸ©2dimâ¢(â„‹^).subscript^ğ‘„ğ‘˜superscriptinner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒ^â„‹delimited-[]subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜2dim^â„‹\hat{Q}_{k}=\frac{\braket{e_{k}}{P_{\hat{\mathcal{H}}}[e_{k}]}^{2}}{\textrm{% dim}(\hat{\mathcal{H}})}.over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG âŸ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG dim ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG ) end_ARG . (8)

Similarly, we can define a cumulative measure of the utility of the first kğ‘˜kitalic_k features, ordered by the size of their eigenvalues:

Î ^â¢(k)=âˆ‘j=1kQ^k^Î ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘„ğ‘˜\hat{\Pi}(k)=\sum_{j=1}^{k}\hat{Q}_{k}over^ start_ARG roman_Î  end_ARG ( italic_k ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (9)

which we will call the cumulative utility. It takes values 0â‰¤Î ^â¢(k)â‰¤10^Î ğ‘˜10\leq\hat{\Pi}(k)\leq 10 â‰¤ over^ start_ARG roman_Î  end_ARG ( italic_k ) â‰¤ 1. Note that typically, dimâ¢(â„‹^)=Cdim^â„‹ğ¶\textrm{dim}(\hat{\mathcal{H}})=Cdim ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG ) = italic_C, since the entries of f^^ğ‘“\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG are likely to be linearly independent. Additionally, the entries of the output function typically exhibit similar norms after training. (i.e. â€–f^iâ€–â‰ˆâ€–f^jâ€–normsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–normsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—\|\hat{f}_{i}\|\approx\|\hat{f}_{j}\|âˆ¥ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰ˆ âˆ¥ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥). By definition, the total utility Î ^â¢(p)=1^Î ğ‘1\hat{\Pi}(p)=1over^ start_ARG roman_Î  end_ARG ( italic_p ) = 1. The smallest kğ‘˜kitalic_k for which Î â¢(p)^â‰ˆ1^Î ğ‘1\hat{\Pi(p)}\approx 1over^ start_ARG roman_Î  ( italic_p ) end_ARG â‰ˆ 1 provides a measure for the effective number of features used by the DNN. By contrast, the total cumulative quality Î âˆ—â¢(p)superscriptÎ ğ‘\Pi^{*}(p)roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) can still be much smaller than 1111 if the training leads to a function f^^ğ‘“\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG that significantly differs from the ground truth fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

2.4 Eigenvalues and effective dimensions

The eigenvalues determine the speed of coefficient learning under MSE loss in a linear model, as shown in Equation 3. They can also be written in the following way:

Ïk=âŸ¨ek|Tâ¢[ek]âŸ©=âŸ¨ek|â¢âˆ‘j=1p|Î¦jâŸ©â¢âŸ¨Î¦j|ekâŸ©=âˆ‘j=1pâŸ¨Î¦j|ekâŸ©2,subscriptğœŒğ‘˜inner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘‡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜brasubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘ketsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘—inner-productsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘—subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptinner-productsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘—subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜2\rho_{k}=\braket{e_{k}}{T[e_{k}]}=\bra{e_{k}}\sum_{j=1}^{p}\ket{\Phi_{j}}% \braket{\Phi_{j}}{e_{k}}=\sum_{j=1}^{p}\braket{\Phi_{j}}{e_{k}}^{2},italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_T [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG âŸ© = âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | start_ARG roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© âŸ¨ start_ARG roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ start_ARG roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (10)

which shows that they are a measure of the projection of Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ along eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in function space. It is therefore of interest to plot the distribution of the pğ‘pitalic_p eigenvalues as a function of index kğ‘˜kitalic_k.

It can also be useful to define scalar measures to characterize these distributions. For any vector ağ‘aitalic_a of positive numbers aisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the exponential of Shannon entropy [Hill, 1973] can be used as a spectral dimension or effective dimension measure:

Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(a)=expâ¢(âˆ’âˆ‘iaiâˆ‘jajâ¢lnâ¡(aiâˆ‘jaj)).subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘expsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—D_{eff}(a)=\textrm{exp}\left(-\sum_{i}\frac{a_{i}}{\sum_{j}a_{j}}\ln\left(% \frac{a_{i}}{\sum_{j}a_{j}}\right)\right).italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) = exp ( - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_ln ( divide start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ) . (11)

If the vector ağ‘aitalic_a has dğ‘‘ditalic_d components, then Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(a)subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘D_{eff}(a)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) has a maximal value of dğ‘‘ditalic_d when all components are equal (and non-zero). If the distribution of its components is non-uniform, then the effective dimension will be lower than dğ‘‘ditalic_d, with a minimum of 1111 if ağ‘aitalic_a only has one non-zero component.

The effective dimension or effective rank of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T can be measured via Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(Ï)subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“ğœŒD_{eff}(\rho)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) where Ï=[Ï1,â‹¯,Ïp]ğœŒsubscriptğœŒ1â‹¯subscriptğœŒğ‘\rho=[\rho_{1},\cdots,\rho_{p}]italic_Ï = [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. In a way that is analogous to the way that entropy quantifies the average number of bits for a symbol in the source coding theorem, this measure implies that although Tğ‘‡Titalic_T has a rank of pğ‘pitalic_p, it can in principle be compressed to an operator of rank Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(Ï)â‰¤psubscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“ğœŒğ‘D_{eff}(\rho)\leq pitalic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) â‰¤ italic_p. From the perspective of Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦, Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(Ï)subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“ğœŒD_{eff}(\rho)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) measures how many eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT you need in expectation to describe Î¦â¢(x)Î¦ğ‘¥\Phi(x)roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) for xâˆ¼qsimilar-toğ‘¥ğ‘x\sim qitalic_x âˆ¼ italic_q. As a practical note, because the first eigenfunction of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T upon full training is typically a constant, as discussed in Section 5.1, Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(Ï)subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“ğœŒD_{eff}(\rho)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) in our study is computed without the first eigenvalue before reintroducing a single dimension (i.e. Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(Ï):=1+Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢([Ï2,â‹¯,Ïp])assignsubscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“ğœŒ1subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“subscriptğœŒ2â‹¯subscriptğœŒğ‘D_{eff}(\rho):=1+D_{eff}([\rho_{2},\cdots,\rho_{p}])italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) := 1 + italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] )).

We can also use Equation 11 to measure the effective dimension Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(Qâˆ—)subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“superscriptğ‘„D_{eff}(Q^{*})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) of the set of feature qualities Qâˆ—=[Q1âˆ—,â‹¯,Qpâˆ—]superscriptğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„1â‹¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘Q^{*}=[Q^{*}_{1},\cdots,Q^{*}_{p}]italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. This provides a measure of the effective number of features needed to express the target function. Because the target function may not always be completely expressible by features, this measure can be interpreted as the effective number of features required for the best possible approximation of the target function, given Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦.

Similarly, we can define Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(Q^)subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“^ğ‘„D_{eff}(\hat{Q})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG ) for the feature utilities Q^=[Q^1,â‹¯,Q^p]^ğ‘„subscript^ğ‘„1â‹¯subscript^ğ‘„ğ‘\hat{Q}=[\hat{Q}_{1},\cdots,\hat{Q}_{p}]over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG = [ over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], which describes the effective number of features used to describe the learned function. We expect that Deâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(Q^)subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“^ğ‘„D_{eff}(\hat{Q})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG ) is roughly the number of features needed to achieve Î ^â¢(k)â‰ˆ1^Î ğ‘˜1\hat{\Pi}(k)\approx 1over^ start_ARG roman_Î  end_ARG ( italic_k ) â‰ˆ 1, which is one measure of the effective number of features used by the DNN to express the learned function f^^ğ‘“\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG.

2.5 Approximating the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues in practice

To calculate the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues using Equation 2 for a given parameter-function map Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦, we also need the true input distribution qğ‘qitalic_q, which is in principle inaccessible. However, we assume that for a large enough training set Stâ¢râˆˆÏ‡subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğœ’S_{tr}\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{% $\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_Ï‡ we can use its nğ‘›nitalic_n datapoints to obtain nğ‘›nitalic_n feature vectors of size pğ‘pitalic_p, and that these provide a good enough estimate of qğ‘qitalic_q that we can use the discrete NystrÃ¶m method [Baker and Taylor, 1979; Williams and Rasmussen, 2006] to extract eigenvalues and eigenfunctions from the integral equation Equation 2 with sufficient accuracy. We perform singular value decomposition (SVD) on the feature matrix Î¦â¢(Stâ¢r)âˆˆâ„pÃ—nÎ¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘›\Phi(S_{tr})\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times n}roman_Î¦ ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to obtain singular values sâˆˆâ„pğ‘ superscriptâ„ğ‘s\in\mathbb{R}^{p}italic_s âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and pğ‘pitalic_p left column eigenvectors ukâˆˆâ„psubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘u_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{p}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. we can approximate empirical eigenvalues of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T by squaring sğ‘ sitalic_s and using the left column eigenvectors ukâˆˆâ„psubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘u_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{p}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, sksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜s_{k}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and feature map Î¦:Ï‡â†’â„p:Î¦â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ‘\Phi:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Î¦ : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to obtain ktâ¢hsuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„k^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT eigenfunction ekâ¢(x)=ukTâ¢Î¦â¢(x)/sksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ‘‡Î¦ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜e_{k}(x)=u_{k}^{T}\Phi(x)/s_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) / italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that the eigenfunctions can be used on any data point beyond the training set. Also, we have implicitly assumed n>pğ‘›ğ‘n>pitalic_n > italic_p, but when n<pğ‘›ğ‘n<pitalic_n < italic_p, we can only approximate up to nğ‘›nitalic_n eigenfunctions and eigenvalues. The algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 1.

To calculate the inner product in Equation 6 involving fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or f^^ğ‘“\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG in Equation 9 we cannot use the training set, because if one trains to zero training error, both functions will be equivalent on Stâ¢rsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘ŸS_{tr}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. So instead, given the eigenfunctions, we use the test set Stâ¢esubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘’S_{te}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to approximate the relevant inner products as follows:

âŸ¨ek|fjâŸ©2â€–ekâ€–22â¢â€–fjâ€–22=(âˆ«Ï‡ekâ¢(x)â¢fjâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘x)2âˆ«Ï‡ekâ¢(x)2â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ¢âˆ«Ï‡fjâ¢(x)2â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ‰ˆ(âˆ‘x(i)âˆˆStâ¢eekâ¢(x(i))â¢fjâ¢(x(i)))2âˆ‘x(i)âˆˆStâ¢eekâ¢(x(i))2â¢âˆ‘x(i)âˆˆStâ¢efjâ¢(x(i))2.superscriptinner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—2subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜22subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—22superscriptsubscriptğœ’subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥2subscriptğœ’subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥subscriptğœ’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘’subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘’subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜superscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–2\frac{\braket{e_{k}}{f_{j}}^{2}}{\|e_{k}\|^{2}_{2}\|f_{j}\|^{2}_{2}}=\frac{% \left(\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt% }{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% italic_x ) italic_d italic_x âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
