  • Zhuang et al. [2020] F. Zhuang, Z. Qi, K. Duan, D. Xi, Y. Zhu, H. Zhu, H. Xiong, and Q. He. A comprehensive survey on transfer learning. Proceedings of the IEEE, 109(1):43â€“76, 2020.

A DNN performance for a fixed feature map as a function of width

In this section, we expand on the experiment in Figure 1(b) where we explore the width pğ‘pitalic_p needed for a DNN with a frozen feature map (random features) to reach (near) zero training error. We compare a CNN, ResNet18 and VGG16 on both CIFAR10 and CIFAR100. In Figure 13 we observe that to first order, a width on the order of pâ‰ˆnğ‘ğ‘›p\approx nitalic_p â‰ˆ italic_n is needed to train a CNN to zero training error on CIFAR10. To second order, this width depends on depth as well, with larger widths needed for deeper CNNs. We explore a much smaller range of widths for ResNet18 and VGG16 architectures for CIFAR10 in Figure 14, and for CIFAR100 in Figure 15. We observe that if the DNN is trained with SGD, both these architectures can reach zero training error for very narrow final layer widths pğ‘pitalic_p, but much larger widths are needed for DNNs with a frozen feature map.

In the main text, we did not study the effects of the widths of the intermediate layers. One could imagine the extreme case of a bottleneck layer inserted just before the penultimate layer, that would greatly reduce expressivity. Here we keep the overall width constant, but it would be interesting to vary the width of intermediate layers.

In more detail: Figure 13 shows a CNN with kernels of size 3Ã—3333\times 33 Ã— 3, a max-pooling layer with kernel size 2Ã—2222\times 22 Ã— 2, and a final linear layer on the flattened output. The output dimension is controlled by the size of this flattened output, meaning that the number of filters per layer determines pğ‘pitalic_p. When the last layer has p=90000ğ‘90000p=90000italic_p = 90000 for the depth 2 CNN, we have 500 filters per layer (increasing depth decreases pğ‘pitalic_p slightly for a fixed number of filters as the image is shrunk by 2 pixels on each dimension with each convolutional layer). Depth counts the number of matrices in the CNN (so a single convolutional layer plus the final layer has depth 2). Figure 13(a) shows that pâˆ¼104similar-toğ‘superscript104p\sim 10^{4}italic_p âˆ¼ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is enough to fit the training data for the depth 2 and 5 models, but for depth 10 and for the maximum width, the model cannot do better than 70% train accuracy. Note also that even when 100% train accuracy can be achieved, generalisation continues to improve with increasing width for the depth 2 and 5 models. Figure 13(b) explores the generalisation error with training set size for the depth 5 model at two different widths. It illustrates how narrower frozen feature models can fit less training data to 100% accuracy, as expected.

B On the definition of features

demonstrating that UTâ¢U=Uâ¢UT=Isuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘‡ğ‘ˆğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘‡ğ¼U^{T}U=UU^{T}=Iitalic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U = italic_U italic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_I, and thus Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U is orthogonal. This argument shows that

fâ¢(x)=âˆ‘k=1p[Ukâ¢jâ¢Î¸j]â¢[Ïkâ¢ekâ¢(x)]ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘delimited-[]subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptğœƒğ‘—delimited-[]subscriptğœŒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\left[U_{kj}\theta_{j}\right]\left[\sqrt{\rho_{k}}e_{k}(x)\right]italic_f ( italic_x ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] [ square-root start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ]

where Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U preserves the norm of Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸. This would mean the norm of a perturbation â€–Î”â¢Î¸â€–2=â€–Î”â¢Î¸â€²â€–2subscriptnormÎ”ğœƒ2subscriptnormÎ”superscriptğœƒâ€²2||{\Delta\theta}||_{2}=||\Delta\theta^{\prime}||_{2}| | roman_Î” italic_Î¸ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | | roman_Î” italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Î¸â€²=Uâ¢Î¸superscriptğœƒâ€²ğ‘ˆğœƒ\theta^{\prime}=U\thetaitalic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_U italic_Î¸. This fact means gradient descent on Î¸â€²superscriptğœƒâ€²\theta^{\prime}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT would find the same solutions as on Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸. For more information on the importance of model parameterisation, see e.g. [Caticha, 2014]. Given this property, it would arguably be desirable to call Ïkâ¢ekâ¢(x)subscriptğœŒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥\sqrt{\rho_{k}}e_{k}(x)square-root start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) the features, as we could write fâ¢(x)=âˆ‘k=1pÎ¸kâ€²â¢zkğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğœƒâ€²ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘§ğ‘˜f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\theta^{\prime}_{k}z_{k}italic_f ( italic_x ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where the features zk=Ïkâ¢ekâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘§ğ‘˜subscriptğœŒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥z_{k}=\sqrt{\rho_{k}}e_{k}(x)italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ).

Furthermore, when the model is overparameterised, the solution found is strongly influenced by ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â€“ so incorporating ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into the definition of features would mean two models with the same features would always find the same solutions. It would be entirely consistent to call features Ïkâ¢|ekâŸ©subscriptğœŒğ‘˜ketsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜\sqrt{\rho_{k}}\ket{e_{k}}square-root start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ©, and then study its two components separately. However, one could also argue that as the eigenfunctions ekâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) are correctly normalized, it would not make sense to call features rescaled eigenfunctions â€“ two models with the same ekâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) but different eigenvalues Ïk,Ïkâ€²subscriptğœŒğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœŒâ€²ğ‘˜\rho_{k},\rho^{\prime}_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would disagree on how much the kâ€™th feature is present in the input. This also seems undesirable.

As a result of these issues, and given that our measures use the correctly normalized ekâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ), or ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT separately, we find it easier to call |ekâŸ©ketsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜\ket{e_{k}}| start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© the features and ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the associated eigenvalue.

It is also worth briefly discussing exactly how the eigenfunctions ekâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) relate to more intuitive pictures of features â€“ as abstract properties of the input (for example, the edge of an object, or the object itself, in image data). It has been shown in e.g. [Krizhevsky et al., 2017] that early layers of CNNs do indeed pick up on edges, and later layers pick up on more abstract features (like chain links) [Graetz, 2019]. It is at present less clear how to make similar interpretations of our final layer features. Future work on intermediate layer features (see also Section D) may help bring some insight, however.

C Further Experiments

In this section, we present a series of further experiments that complement various points made in the main text.

D Intermediate layer features

In the main text, we only study the final layer features. Analysing the middle layers is necessary for a complete understanding of feature learning. This appendix shows how we can straightforwardly apply measures outlined in Section 2, and discusses the problems with doing this. See e.g. [Alain and Bengio, 2016; Montavon et al., 2011; Lou et al., 2022] for related work.

Intermediate layers have an intermediate feature map in the same way the last layer does. The feature map of the lğ‘™litalic_lâ€™th layer is Î¦(l):Ï‡â†’â„pl:superscriptÎ¦ğ‘™â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘ğ‘™\Phi^{(l)}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt% }{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p_{l}}roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where plsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™p_{l}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the number of features for layer lğ‘™litalic_l. This induces a feature kernel for the lğ‘™litalic_lâ€™th layer, Î¦(l)â¢(x)Tâ¢Î¦(l)â¢(xâ€²)superscriptÎ¦ğ‘™superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡superscriptÎ¦ğ‘™superscriptğ‘¥â€²\Phi^{(l)}(x)^{T}\Phi^{(l)}(x^{\prime})roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Its eigenvalues, eigenfunctions and all projection measures in Section 2 can be defined in exactly the same way that they are for the last layer. When the output of the feature map Î¦(l)superscriptÎ¦ğ‘™\Phi^{(l)}roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is multidimensional (e.g. the output from a 2D convolutional module), the output is flattened to a vector (similarly to [Montavon et al., 2011; Alain and Bengio, 2016; Raghu et al., 2017]).

The interpretation of Î¦(l)superscriptÎ¦ğ‘™\Phi^{(l)}roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as an intermediate feature map and measuring its change with training to monitor feature learning in intermediate layers is straightforward. We use the measures Î âˆ—superscriptÎ \Pi^{*}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Î ^^Î \hat{\Pi}over^ start_ARG roman_Î  end_ARG, which capture how aligned a layer is to the target function and learned function respectively. It is straightforward to simply consider these as probes that help quantify the amount of feature learning that occurs under training. However, more care is needed in their direct interpretation. In contrast to the final-layer features these layers are not used to directly produce measured output, but rather are fed into the next layer. If well-trained early layers are strongly aligned to the final target, that may not be a good thing. We illustrate this in Figure 21 where a greedy layerwise training method leads to stronger alignment in earlier layers, but less good performance than normal SGD with backpropagation for a ResNet18 on CIFAR10.

In more detail, to generate Figure 21, we use a version of greedy layerwise training [Ivakhnenko and Lapa, 1965]. We append an auxiliary classification layer to the first layer, training that system, before removing the auxiliary layer, freezing the first layer, and repeating the process with the second layer. Even though it is sometimes possible to achieve near-SOTA accuracies with such a method [Belilovsky et al., 2019], the greedy layerwise training typically leads to worse performance than full backpropagation. In Figure 21(a), the layerwise training generates significantly greater alignment Î âˆ—â¢(k)superscriptÎ ğ‘˜\Pi^{*}(k)roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) at lower kğ‘˜kitalic_k in layers 1 and 2, compared to full backpropagation. However, the feature quality does not continue to improve in layers 3 and 4, and Î âˆ—â¢(p)superscriptÎ ğ‘\Pi^{*}(p)roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) for the last layer is significantly lower than for backpropagation. In Figure 21(b) we observe that layerwise training, compared to backpropagation, has a larger increment of Î ^â¢(k)^Î ğ‘˜\hat{\Pi}(k)over^ start_ARG roman_Î  end_ARG ( italic_k ) for the first 3 layers, but a negligible difference between the 4tâ¢hsuperscript4ğ‘¡â„4^{th}4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the last layer. In addition, both systems are very close to the full MF regime. This is another example where the MF regime holds for two training methods, but performance varies significantly, as discussed in Section 4.1. Finally, in Figure 21(c), we observe that the eigenvalue spectrum reflects how the standard backpropagation training only produces a clear MF regime structure in the final layer. In contrast, greedy training produces a more MF regime-like pattern in earlier layers, as all intermediate layers are treated as penultimate layers in the training process.

We also study the effect of batchnorm on the intermediate layer features in Figure 22 for two cases where it makes a big difference to generalisation performance. Subfigure (a) shows VGG16 on Cifar100 and (b) ResNet18 on Cifar100. In both cases, early layers barely align to the target function without batchnorm and perform significantly worse than the case with batch norm. This provides an example of how intermediate layers help diagnose the causes of the reduced performance. We leave further experiments and analysis to future work, including an upcoming companion paper on intermediate features.

E Two lemmas

In this section, we provide the proofs of two lemmas that are used in the main text. Throughout, we assume an infinite number of data and the following MSE loss.

ğ‹=âˆ«Ï‡(fâ¢(x)âˆ’fâˆ—â¢(x))2â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xğ‹subscriptğœ’superscriptğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘“ğ‘¥2ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥\mathbf{L}=\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{% 0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0% pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\left(f(x)-f^{*}(x)\right)^{2}q(x)dxbold_L = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (27)
Lemma 1.

The Gradient Flow (GF) dynamics of a linear model of the following form fâ¢(x)=âˆ‘i=1pÎ¸iâ¢Î¦iâ¢(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğœƒğ‘–subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–ğ‘¥f(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{p}\theta_{i}\Phi_{i}(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) is diagonalized into the following pğ‘pitalic_p independent equations:

âŸ¨f|ekâŸ©â¢(t)=âŸ¨fâˆ—|ekâŸ©â¢(1âˆ’eâˆ’Î·â¢Ïkâ¢t),inner-productğ‘“subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡inner-productsuperscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘’ğœ‚subscriptğœŒğ‘˜ğ‘¡\braket{f}{e_{k}}(t)=\braket{f^{*}}{e_{k}}(1-e^{-\eta\rho_{k}t}),âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© ( italic_t ) = âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î· italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (28)

where ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of the intergral operator Tğ‘‡Titalic_T (Equation 2), and Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· is the learning rate.

Proof  By using the gradient descent equation (dâ¢Î¸idâ¢t=âˆ’Î·â¢dâ¢ğ‹dâ¢Î¸iğ‘‘subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘‘ğ‹ğ‘‘subscriptğœƒğ‘–\frac{d\theta_{i}}{dt}=-\eta\frac{d\mathbf{L}}{d\theta_{i}}divide start_ARG italic_d italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG = - italic_Î· divide start_ARG italic_d bold_L end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG), we can write the change of fğ‘“fitalic_f as

dâ¢fdâ¢tâ¢(xâ€²)ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥â€²\displaystyle\frac{df}{dt}(x^{\prime})divide start_ARG italic_d italic_f end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =âˆ‘ipdâ¢Î¸idâ¢tâ¢Î¦iâ¢(xâ€²)=âˆ‘ipâˆ’Î·â¢dâ¢ğ‹dâ¢Î¸iâ¢Î¦iâ¢(xâ€²)absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘‘subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘¡subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘ğœ‚ğ‘‘ğ‹ğ‘‘subscriptğœƒğ‘–subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥â€²\displaystyle=\sum_{i}^{p}\frac{d\theta_{i}}{dt}\Phi_{i}(x^{\prime})=\sum_{i}^% {p}-\eta\frac{d\mathbf{L}}{d\theta_{i}}\Phi_{i}(x^{\prime})= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_d italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î· divide start_ARG italic_d bold_L end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (29)
=âˆ’2â¢Î·â¢âˆ«Ï‡(fâ¢(x)âˆ’fâˆ—â¢(x))â¢âˆ‘ipdâ¢fdâ¢Î¸iâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢dâ¢xâ¢Î¦iâ¢(xâ€²)absent2ğœ‚subscriptğœ’ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘‘subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¥subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥â€²\displaystyle=-2\eta\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\left(f(x)-f^{*}(x)\right)\sum_{i}% ^{p}\frac{df}{d\theta_{i}}(x)q(x)dx\Phi_{i}(x^{\prime})= - 2 italic_Î· âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_d italic_f end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (30)
=âˆ’2â¢Î·â¢âˆ«Ï‡(fâ¢(x)âˆ’fâˆ—â¢(x))â¢âˆ‘ipÎ¦iâ¢(x)â¢Î¦iâ¢(xâ€²)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢dâ¢xabsent2ğœ‚subscriptğœ’ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¥\displaystyle=-2\eta\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\left(f(x)-f^{*}(x)\right)\sum_{i}% ^{p}\Phi_{i}(x)\Phi_{i}(x^{\prime})q(x)dx= - 2 italic_Î· âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (31)
=âˆ’2â¢Î·â¢Tâ¢[fâˆ’fâˆ—]â¢(xâ€²)absent2ğœ‚ğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ‘“superscriptğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â€²\displaystyle=-2\eta T\left[f-f^{*}\right](x^{\prime})= - 2 italic_Î· italic_T [ italic_f - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (32)

The equation mimics the form of a matrix differential equation. If we take the inner product of both sides with eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

dâ¢âŸ¨ek|fâŸ©dâ¢tğ‘‘inner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘“ğ‘‘ğ‘¡\displaystyle\frac{d\braket{e_{k}}{f}}{dt}divide start_ARG italic_d âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f end_ARG âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG =âˆ’2â¢Î·â¢âŸ¨ek|Tâ¢[fâˆ’fâˆ—]âŸ©absent2ğœ‚inner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ‘“superscriptğ‘“\displaystyle=-2\eta\braket{e_{k}}{T\left[f-f^{*}\right]}= - 2 italic_Î· âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_T [ italic_f - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] end_ARG âŸ© (33)
=âˆ’2â¢Î·â¢Ïkâ¢(âŸ¨ek|fâŸ©âˆ’âŸ¨ek|fâˆ—âŸ©),absent2ğœ‚subscriptğœŒğ‘˜inner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘“inner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘“\displaystyle=-2\eta\rho_{k}\left(\braket{e_{k}}{f}-\braket{e_{k}}{f^{*}}% \right),= - 2 italic_Î· italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f end_ARG âŸ© - âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© ) , (34)

where we used that fact that Tğ‘‡Titalic_T is symmetric operator and Tâ¢[ek]=Ïkâ¢ekğ‘‡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜subscriptğœŒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜T[e_{k}]=\rho_{k}e_{k}italic_T [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Solving the differential equation for âŸ¨ek|fâŸ©inner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘“\braket{e_{k}}{f}âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f end_ARG âŸ© with initial condition of âŸ¨ek|fâŸ©â¢(0)=0inner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘“00\braket{e_{k}}{f}(0)=0âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f end_ARG âŸ© ( 0 ) = 0 leads to

âŸ¨f|ekâŸ©â¢(t)=âŸ¨fâˆ—|ekâŸ©â¢(1âˆ’eâˆ’Î·â¢Ïkâ¢t).inner-productğ‘“subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡inner-productsuperscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘’ğœ‚subscriptğœŒğ‘˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle\braket{f}{e_{k}}(t)=\braket{f^{*}}{e_{k}}(1-e^{-\eta\rho_{k}t}).âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© ( italic_t ) = âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î· italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (35)

 

Lemma 2.

When T=TMâ¢Pğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘€ğ‘ƒT=T_{MP}italic_T = italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a DNN, there is one-to-one mapping between Î¦â¢(x)Î¦ğ‘¥\Phi(x)roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) and f^â¢(x)^ğ‘“ğ‘¥\hat{f}(x)over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) on the support of qğ‘qitalic_q.

Proof  The MP operator, by definition, maps from the expressed function space â„‹^^â„‹\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG to â„‹^^â„‹\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG. The entries of the feature map [Î¦1,â‹¯,Î¦p]subscriptÎ¦1â‹¯subscriptÎ¦ğ‘[\Phi_{1},\cdots,\Phi_{p}][ roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] span â„‹^^â„‹\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG, and entries of the expressed function ([f^1,â‹¯,f^C]subscript^ğ‘“1â‹¯subscript^ğ‘“ğ¶[\hat{f}_{1},\cdots,\hat{f}_{C}][ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]), by definition, also span â„‹^^â„‹\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG. Since Î¦â¢(x)Î¦ğ‘¥\Phi(x)roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) and f^â¢(x)^ğ‘“ğ‘¥\hat{f}(x)over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) are related by a linear transform â€“ ignoring the bias term as constant function is in â„‹^^â„‹\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG â€“ the map between Î¦â¢(x)Î¦ğ‘¥\Phi(x)roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) and f^â¢(x)^ğ‘“ğ‘¥\hat{f}(x)over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) is one-to-one.

Assuming our input xğ‘¥xitalic_x is a discrete random variable, Î¦â¢(x)Î¦ğ‘¥\Phi(x)roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) and f^â¢(x)^ğ‘“ğ‘¥\hat{f}(x)over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) are also discrete random variables. The one-to-one relationship then is sufficient to prove that mutual information between two random variables is 0 (i.e. Iâ¢(Î¦â¢(x);f^â¢(x))=0ğ¼Î¦ğ‘¥^ğ‘“ğ‘¥0I(\Phi(x);\hat{f}(x))=0italic_I ( roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) ; over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) ) = 0).  

F Proofs related to Neural Collapse

In this section, we state the relevant terms and the four NC conditions given in [Han et al., 2021]. Please note that the current study assumes column-vectors for all vectors (e.g. Î¼iâˆˆâ„pÃ—1subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘1\mu_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times 1}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p Ã— 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). The last layer can be defined in the following manner

f^iâ¢(x)=wiTâ¢Î¦â¢(x)+bisubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘‡Î¦ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\hat{f}_{i}(x)=w_{i}^{T}\Phi(x)+b_{i}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (36)

where wiâˆˆâ„pÃ—1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘1w_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times 1}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p Ã— 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the parameter of the last that projects the feature onto the itâ¢hsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡â„i^{th}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry of the output function. biâˆˆâ„subscriptğ‘ğ‘–â„b_{i}\in\mathbb{R}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R is the corresponding bias term. The feature class mean or the mean of features with label iğ‘–iitalic_i is

Î¼i=Cnâ¢âˆ‘x(j)âˆˆAiÎ¦â¢(x(j)).subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ¶ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğ´ğ‘–Î¦superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—\mu_{i}=\frac{C}{n}\sum_{x^{(j)}\in A_{i}}\Phi(x^{(j)}).italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_C end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (37)

The global mean is

Î¼g=1Câ¢âˆ‘iCÎ¼i.subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”1ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ¶subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–\mu_{g}=\frac{1}{C}\sum_{i}^{C}\mu_{i}.italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (38)

The feature within-class covariance Î£Wâˆˆâ„pÃ—psubscriptÎ£ğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘\Sigma_{W}\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times p}roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p Ã— italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is

Î£W:=1nâ¢âˆ‘iCâˆ‘x(j)âˆˆAi(hiâ¢(x(j))âˆ’Î¼i)â¢(hiâ¢(x(j))âˆ’Î¼i)T.assignsubscriptÎ£ğ‘Š1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ¶subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘‡\Sigma_{W}:=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}^{C}\sum_{x^{(j)}\in A_{i}}(h_{i}(x^{(j)})-\mu_% {i})(h_{i}(x^{(j)})-\mu_{i})^{T}.roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (39)

The feature between-class covariance Î£bâˆˆâ„pÃ—psubscriptÎ£ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘\Sigma_{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times p}roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p Ã— italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is

Î£b:=1Câ¢âˆ‘iC(Î¼iâˆ’Î¼g)â¢(Î¼iâˆ’Î¼g)T.assignsubscriptÎ£ğ‘1ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ¶subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”ğ‘‡\Sigma_{b}:=\frac{1}{C}\sum_{i}^{C}(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})^{T}.roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (40)

The four NC conditions are the following Papyan et al. [2020]:

  1. 1.

    Within class variance tends to 0

    Î£Wâ¢Î£bTâ†’0â†’subscriptÎ£ğ‘ŠsuperscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘ğ‘‡0\Sigma_{W}\Sigma_{b}^{T}\rightarrow 0roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ 0 (41)
  2. 2.

    Convergence to simplex ETF

    (Î¼iâˆ’Î¼g)Tâ¢(Î¼jâˆ’Î¼g)â€–(Î¼iâˆ’Î¼g)â€–2â¢â€–(Î¼jâˆ’Î¼g)â€–2â†’Câ¢Î´iâ¢jâˆ’1Câˆ’1â†’superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‡ğ‘—subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”subscriptnormsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”2subscriptnormsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘—subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”2ğ¶subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ¶1\frac{(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})^{T}(\mu_{j}-\mu_{g})}{\|(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})\|_{2}\|(\mu_% {j}-\mu_{g})\|_{2}}\rightarrow\frac{C\delta_{ij}-1}{C-1}divide start_ARG ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â†’ divide start_ARG italic_C italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C - 1 end_ARG (42)
  3. 3.

    Convergence to self duality

    wiâ€–wiâ€–2âˆ’Î¼iâˆ’Î¼gâ€–(Î¼iâˆ’Î¼g)â€–2â†’0â†’subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–2subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”subscriptnormsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”20\frac{w_{i}}{\|w_{i}\|_{2}}-\frac{\mu_{i}-\mu_{g}}{\|(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})\|_{2}}\rightarrow 0divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â†’ 0 (43)
  4. 4.

    Simplification to nearest class center

    argâ¡maxiâ¡wiâ¢Î¦â¢(x)+biâ†’argâ¡miniâ¡â€–Î¦â¢(x)âˆ’Î¼iâ€–2â†’subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–Î¦ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–subscriptnormÎ¦ğ‘¥subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–2\arg\max_{i}w_{i}\Phi(x)+b_{i}\rightarrow\arg\min_{i}\|\Phi(x)-\mu_{i}\|_{2}roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (44)

See 1

Proof  By the definition of indicator functions of equal partitions,

âŸ¨f^i|f^jâŸ©=1Câ¢Î´iâ¢j,âˆ‘iCf^i=ğŸ,âŸ¨ğŸ|f^jâŸ©=1Cformulae-sequenceinner-productsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—1ğ¶subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ¶subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–1inner-product1subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—1ğ¶\braket{\hat{f}_{i}}{\hat{f}_{j}}=\frac{1}{C}\delta_{ij},\quad\quad\sum_{i}^{C% }\hat{f}_{i}=\mathbf{1},\quad\quad\braket{\mathbf{1}}{\hat{f}_{j}}=\frac{1}{C}âŸ¨ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_1 , âŸ¨ start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG | start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG (45)

Since Câ¢f^jâˆ’ğŸğ¶subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—1C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 is orthogonal to ğŸ1\mathbf{1}bold_1,

TMâ¢Pâ¢[Câ¢f^jâˆ’ğŸ]=a2â¢(Câ¢f^jâˆ’ğŸ)subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘€ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]ğ¶subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘2ğ¶subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—1T_{MP}[C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}]=a_{2}(C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1})italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ] = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ) (46)

where we used the definition of MP operators Equation 13. Then from Equation 45 and Equation 46,

âŸ¨Câ¢ğŸi|TMâ¢Pâ¢[Câ¢f^jâˆ’ğŸ]âŸ©=a2â¢âŸ¨Câ¢ğŸi|Câ¢f^jâˆ’ğŸâŸ©=a2â¢(Câ¢Î´iâ¢jâˆ’ğŸ)inner-productğ¶subscriptğŸğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘€ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]ğ¶subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘2inner-productğ¶subscriptğŸğ‘–ğ¶subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘2ğ¶subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—1\braket{C\mathbf{f}_{i}}{T_{MP}[C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}]}=a_{2}\braket{C% \mathbf{f}_{i}}{C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}}=a_{2}(C\delta_{ij}-\mathbf{1})\\ âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_C bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ] end_ARG âŸ© = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_C bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 end_ARG âŸ© = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ) (47)

Likewise,

âŸ¨ğŸ|TMâ¢Pâ¢[Câ¢f^jâˆ’ğŸ]âŸ©=a2â¢âŸ¨ğŸ|Câ¢f^jâˆ’ğŸâŸ©=0.inner-product1subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘€ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]ğ¶subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘2inner-product1ğ¶subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—10\braket{\mathbf{1}}{T_{MP}[C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}]}=a_{2}\braket{\mathbf{1}}{% C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}}=0.\\ âŸ¨ start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG | start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ] end_ARG âŸ© = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¨ start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG | start_ARG italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 end_ARG âŸ© = 0 . (48)

 

See 3

Proof  From the translation of class mean function Equation 21,

Î¼iTâ¢Î¼jsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‡ğ‘—\displaystyle\mu_{i}^{T}\mu_{j}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =C2â¢(âˆ«Ï‡f^iâ¢(x)â¢Î¦â¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘x)Tâ¢âˆ«Ï‡f^jâ¢(xâ€²)â¢Î¦â¢(xâ€²)â¢qâ¢(xâ€²)â¢ğ‘‘xâ€²absentsuperscriptğ¶2superscriptsubscriptğœ’subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥ğ‘‡subscriptğœ’subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥â€²Î¦superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²differential-dsuperscriptğ‘¥â€²\displaystyle=C^{2}\left(\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi% $}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)\Phi(x)q(x)dx\right)% ^{T}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{% $\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{j}(x^{\prime})\Phi(x^{\prime})q(x^{\prime})% dx^{\prime}= italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) roman_Î¦ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_d italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (49)
=C2â¢âˆ«Ï‡f^iâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢âˆ«Ï‡Î¦â¢(x)Tâ¢Î¦â¢(xâ€²)â¢f^jâ¢(xâ€²)â¢qâ¢(xâ€²)â¢ğ‘‘xâ€²â¢ğ‘‘xabsentsuperscriptğ¶2subscriptğœ’subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğœ’Î¦superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡Î¦superscriptğ‘¥â€²subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²differential-dsuperscriptğ‘¥â€²differential-dğ‘¥\displaystyle=C^{2}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)q(x)\int_{% \mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x)^{T}\Phi(x^{\prime})\hat{f}_{j}(x^{\prime})q(% x^{\prime})dx^{\prime}dx= italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_d italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_x (50)
=C2â¢âˆ«Ï‡f^iâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢Tâ¢[f^j]â¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xabsentsuperscriptğ¶2subscriptğœ’subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘‡delimited-[]subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥\displaystyle=C^{2}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)q(x)T[\hat{f}_{j}](x% )dx= italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_T [ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (51)
=C2â¢âŸ¨f^i,Tâ¢[f^j]âŸ©.absentsuperscriptğ¶2expectationsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘‡delimited-[]subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—\displaystyle=C^{2}\braket{\hat{f}_{i},T[\hat{f}_{j}]}.= italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T [ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG âŸ© . (52)

Likewise, using Equation 20, we get

Î¼iTâ¢Î¼gsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”\displaystyle\mu_{i}^{T}\mu_{g}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =Câ¢(âˆ«Ï‡f^iâ¢(x)â¢Î¦â¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘x)Tâ¢âˆ«Ï‡Î¦â¢(xâ€²)â¢qâ¢(xâ€²)â¢ğ‘‘xâ€²absentğ¶superscriptsubscriptğœ’subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥ğ‘‡subscriptğœ’Î¦superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²differential-dsuperscriptğ‘¥â€²\displaystyle=C\left(\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)\Phi(x)q(x)dx\right)% ^{T}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{% $\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x^{\prime})q(x^{\prime})dx^{\prime}= italic_C ( âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_d italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (53)
=Câ¢âˆ«Ï‡f^iâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢âˆ«Ï‡Î¦â¢(x)Tâ¢Î¦â¢(xâ€²)â¢qâ¢(xâ€²)â¢ğ‘‘xâ€²â¢ğ‘‘xabsentğ¶subscriptğœ’subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğœ’Î¦superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡Î¦superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²differential-dsuperscriptğ‘¥â€²differential-dğ‘¥\displaystyle=C\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)q(x)\int_{% \mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x)^{T}\Phi(x^{\prime})q(x^{\prime})dx^{\prime}dx= italic_C âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_d italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_x (54)
=Câ¢âˆ«Ï‡f^iâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢Tâ¢[ğŸ]â¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xabsentğ¶subscriptğœ’subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘‡delimited-[]1ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥\displaystyle=C\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)q(x)T[\mathbf{1}](x)dx= italic_C âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_T [ bold_1 ] ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (55)
=Câ¢âŸ¨f^i,Tâ¢[ğŸ]âŸ©.absentğ¶expectationsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘‡delimited-[]1\displaystyle=C\braket{\hat{f}_{i},T[\mathbf{1}]}.= italic_C âŸ¨ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T [ bold_1 ] end_ARG âŸ© . (56)

Then

(Î¼iâˆ’Î¼g)Tâ¢(Î¼jâˆ’Î¼g)superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‡ğ‘—subscriptğœ‡ğ‘”\displaystyle(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})^{T}(\mu_{j}-\mu_{g})( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =âŸ¨Câ¢f^iâˆ’ğŸ,Tâ¢[Câ¢f^jâˆ’ğŸ]âŸ©absentexpectationğ¶subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–1ğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ¶subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—1\displaystyle=\braket{C\hat{f}_{i}-\mathbf{1},T[C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}]}= âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 , italic_T [ italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ] end_ARG âŸ© (57)
=Câ¢a2â¢(Î´iâ¢jâˆ’1C)absentğ¶subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ¶\displaystyle=Ca_{2}(\delta_{ij}-\frac{1}{C})= italic_C italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG ) (58)

which is the NC2 condition, where we used Equation 49 and Equation 53 in the first line and Proposition 1 in the second line.  

See 2

and from Equation 21 and Equation 20

Applying Proposition 1 into the two equations above, we obtain

(62)

Plugging Equation 62 into Equation 59, we obtain

Nâ¢Câ¢1ğ‘ğ¶1\displaystyle NC1italic_N italic_C 1 =a22â¢C2â¢âˆ‘i,jâˆ«Ï‡f^iâ¢(x)â¢(f^jâ¢(x)âˆ’Î´iâ¢j)2â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xabsentsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘22superscriptğ¶2subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ’subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—2ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥\displaystyle=a^{2}_{2}C^{2}\sum_{i,j}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)% \left(\hat{f}_{j}(x)-\delta_{ij}\right)^{2}q(x)dx= italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ( over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (63)
=a22â¢C2â¢âˆ‘i,jâˆ«Ï‡f^iâ¢(x)â¢(f^jâ¢(x)â¢(1âˆ’2â¢Î´iâ¢j)+Î´iâ¢j)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xabsentsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘22superscriptğ¶2subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ’subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥12subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥\displaystyle=a^{2}_{2}C^{2}\sum_{i,j}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)% (\hat{f}_{j}(x)(1-2\delta_{ij})+\delta_{ij})q(x)dx= italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ( over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ( 1 - 2 italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (64)
=a22â¢Câ¢âˆ‘i,j(Î´iâ¢jâ¢(2âˆ’2â¢Î´iâ¢j))absentsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘22ğ¶subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—22subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle=a^{2}_{2}C\sum_{i,j}\left(\delta_{ij}(2-2\delta_{ij})\right)= italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 2 - 2 italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) (65)

where in the third line, we used âŸ¨f^i|f^jâŸ©=Î´iâ¢jâ¢Câˆ’1inner-productsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptğ¶1\braket{\hat{f}_{i}}{\hat{f}_{j}}=\delta_{ij}C^{-1}âŸ¨ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© = italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and âŸ¨f^i|1âŸ©=Câˆ’1inner-productsubscript^ğ‘“ğ‘–1superscriptğ¶1\braket{\hat{f}_{i}}{1}=C^{-1}âŸ¨ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG 1 end_ARG âŸ© = italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.  

G Experimental details

G.1 Architecture details

kÃ—kğ‘˜ğ‘˜k\times kitalic_k Ã— italic_k Conv(â‹…,â‹…,â‹…,â‹…)â‹…â‹…â‹…â‹…(\cdot,\cdot,\cdot,\cdot)( â‹… , â‹… , â‹… , â‹… ) refers to the 2d convolutional module with a kernel of size kğ‘˜kitalic_kxkğ‘˜kitalic_k, and arguments within parenthesis refer to the input channel, output channel, stride, and padding respectively. Linear(â‹…,â‹…)â‹…â‹…(\cdot,\cdot)( â‹… , â‹… ) refers to the fully connected module with the arguments referring to input width and output width respectively. MaxPool(â‹…,â‹…,â‹…)â‹…â‹…â‹…(\cdot,\cdot,\cdot)( â‹… , â‹… , â‹… ) refers to max pooling with the arguments as kernel size, stride, and padding respectively. Adaptive Avgpool(â‹…,â‹…)â‹…â‹…(\cdot,\cdot)( â‹… , â‹… ) refers to adaptive average pooling where arguments are the size of the image after pooling. The curved arrow refers to the skip connection (identity), and any modules that appear in the arrow are applied. BN refers to batch normalization and (BN, ReLU) refers to the application of batch normalization and ReLU in respective order. The definition of the term â€œlayerâ€ for each model is also provided.

G.2 Learning rate and hyperparameters

In our experiments, unless explicitly stated, SGD with a momentum of 0.9 and weight decay of 0.001 was used. Adam [Kingma and Ba, 2014] was used when the model did not converge with SGD. All models were trained for 200, 400, or 600 epochs: the earliest epoch that achieves above 99% training accuracy. For models trained for 200 epochs, a scheduler with 0.2 decay for every 60 epochs was used. For models that require 400 or more epochs, the scheduler was removed. If the model did not converge in 600 epochs or achieve below 99% training accuracy, it would be explicitly mentioned.

CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 were normalized to the mean of (0.4914, 0.4822, 0.4465) and standard deviation of (0.2023, 0.1994, 0.2010). For data augmentation, a random crop of 32 with padding of 4 and a random horizontal flip was used. No augmentation or whitening was applied to the MNIST dataset.

G.3 Loss

We use MSE loss with a centered one-hot vector (i.e. âˆ‘icfiâˆ—â¢(x)=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥0\sum_{i}^{c}f^{*}_{i}(x)=0âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = 0 for all xâˆˆÏ‡ğ‘¥ğœ’x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_x âˆˆ italic_Ï‡) as the Cğ¶Citalic_C dimensional target function fâˆ—:Ï‡â†’â„C:superscriptğ‘“â†’ğœ’superscriptâ„ğ¶f^{*}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_Ï‡ â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Before centering, we have scaled the fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by a factor of 3 for CIFAR10 and MNIST; and by 10 for CIFAR100.

H Accuracy of approximation methods

In the main text, we proposed three main measures of features: quality Qâˆ—superscriptğ‘„Q^{*}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, utility Q^^ğ‘„\hat{Q}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG, and eigenvalues (or intensity) ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï. These measures require the true input distribution qğ‘qitalic_q, which we cannot access in practice. The approximation method for these measures was described in Section 2.5 â€“ the NystrÃ¶m method for approximating eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the Riemann sum for the inner product in qğ‘qitalic_q. In this section, we use empirical methods - where the true eigenfunctions and eigenvalues are known- to assess the validity of NystrÃ¶m method in approximating eigenvalues and eigenfunctions. We also discuss why quality and utility were presented in a cumulative manner (Î âˆ—superscriptÎ \Pi^{*}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Î ^^Î \hat{\Pi}over^ start_ARG roman_Î  end_ARG) while the eigenvalues (ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) are presented directly.

H.1 The NystrÃ¶m method

As discussed in Section 2.5, the NystrÃ¶m method diagonalizes the empirical feature matrix Î¦â¢(X)âˆˆâ„pÃ—nÎ¦ğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘›\Phi(X)\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times n}roman_Î¦ ( italic_X ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to approximate the eigenfunctions eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and eigenvalues ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is more explicitly written in lines 6 and 7 of Algorithm 1:

Ïkâ†sk2,ekâ¢(x)â†ukTâ¢Î¦â¢(x)/sk,formulae-sequenceâ†subscriptğœŒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜2â†subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ‘‡Î¦ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜\rho_{k}\leftarrow s_{k}^{2},\quad\quad e_{k}(x)\leftarrow u_{k}^{T}\Phi(x)/s_% {k},italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â† italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) â† italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) / italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (67)

where uğ‘¢uitalic_u and sğ‘ sitalic_s are the left orthogonal matrix and singular values obtained from singular value decomposition of Î¦â¢(X)Î¦ğ‘‹\Phi(X)roman_Î¦ ( italic_X ).

H.1.1 Experiment setup for testing NystrÃ¶m method

The accuracy of the NystrÃ¶m method depends on the accuracy of singular values (sksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜s_{k}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and left eigenvectors (uksubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜u_{k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) of a random matrix (Î¦â¢(X)Î¦ğ‘‹\Phi(X)roman_Î¦ ( italic_X )). To empirically assess the accuracy of the method, we will use pğ‘pitalic_p independent Gaussian random variables to sample our feature matrix. A power-law distribution with exponent Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± will be used as the eigenvalues:

Î¦kâ¢(x)âˆ¼Ïkâ¢ğ’©â¢(0,1),Ïk=kâˆ’Î±.formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğœŒğ‘˜ğ’©01subscriptğœŒğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜ğ›¼\Phi_{k}(x)\sim\sqrt{\rho_{k}}\mathcal{N}(0,1),\quad\quad\rho_{k}=k^{-\alpha}.roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) âˆ¼ square-root start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ) , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (68)

Gaussian random variables serve as valid features since the features are random variables - xâˆ¼qsimilar-toğ‘¥ğ‘x\sim qitalic_x âˆ¼ italic_q is a random variable, and eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a fixed map, thus ekâ¢(x),subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥e_{k}(x),italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , xâˆ¼qsimilar-toğ‘¥ğ‘x\sim qitalic_x âˆ¼ italic_q is also a random variable - and are orthogonal to other eigenfunctions:

ekâ¢(x):Zkâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1),âŸ¨ei|ejâŸ©=12â¢Ï€â¢âˆ«Zi,ZjZiâ¢Zjâ¢eâˆ’12â¢(Zi2+Zj2)â¢ğ‘‘Ziâ¢ğ‘‘Zj=Î´iâ¢j.:subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ’©01inner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–subscriptğ‘’ğ‘—12ğœ‹subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—superscriptğ‘’12superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—2differential-dsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–differential-dsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—e_{k}(x):Z_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1),\quad\quad\braket{e_{i}}{e_{j}}=\frac{1}{2% \pi}\int_{Z_{i},Z_{j}}Z_{i}Z_{j}e^{-\frac{1}{2}(Z_{i}^{2}+Z_{j}^{2})}dZ_{i}dZ_% {j}=\delta_{ij}.italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) : italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ) , âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ï€ end_ARG âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (69)

Eigenfunctions can also be expressed with Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ as

ekâ¢(x)=okTâ¢Î¦â¢(x)/Ïksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘œğ‘˜ğ‘‡Î¦ğ‘¥subscriptğœŒğ‘˜e_{k}(x)=o_{k}^{T}\Phi(x)/\sqrt{\rho_{k}}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) / square-root start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG (70)

where okâˆˆğ©subscriptğ‘œğ‘˜ğ©o_{k}\in\mathbf{p}italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ bold_p is one-hot vector with its ktâ¢hsuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„k^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry equal to 1111 and all other entries 00 (i.e. ok=[0,â‹¯,0,1,0,â‹¯,0]subscriptğ‘œğ‘˜0â‹¯010â‹¯0o_{k}=[0,\cdots,0,1,0,\cdots,0]italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ 0 , â‹¯ , 0 , 1 , 0 , â‹¯ , 0 ]). Indeed we can check that eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the eigenfunction of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T with eigenvalue ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

=Ïkâ¢ek,absentsubscriptğœŒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\rho_{k}e_{k},= italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (74)

where in the second line, we used that okTsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘œğ‘‡ğ‘˜o^{T}_{k}italic_o start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a one-hot vector.

H.1.2 Accuracy measures

With the underlying true features and eigenvalues defined, we propose measures for calculating the accuracy of approximated values obtained via Algorithm 1.

The error of eigenvalue is measured as square distance between ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (true value) and sk2â¢(X)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜2ğ‘‹s_{k}^{2}(X)italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X ) (approximation) normalized by ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

EXâ¢[(sk2â¢(X)âˆ’Ïk)2Ïk2],subscriptEğ‘‹delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜2ğ‘‹subscriptğœŒğ‘˜2superscriptsubscriptğœŒğ‘˜2\mathrm{E}_{X}\left[\frac{(s_{k}^{2}(X)-\rho_{k})^{2}}{\rho_{k}^{2}}\right],roman_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X ) - italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ] , (75)

Note that EXâ¢[]subscriptEğ‘‹\mathrm{E}_{X}[]roman_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ] means expectation over all possible features matrices Î¦â¢(X)Î¦ğ‘‹\Phi(X)roman_Î¦ ( italic_X ).

The error of eigenfunction is measured as 1111 minus the inner product between ukâ¢(X)âˆˆâ„psubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘u_{k}(X)\in\mathbb{R}^{p}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and oksubscriptğ‘œğ‘˜o_{k}italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

1âˆ’ğ„Xâ¢[|ukTâ¢ok|].1subscriptğ„ğ‘‹delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘œğ‘˜1-\mathbf{E}_{X}\left[|u_{k}^{T}o_{k}|\right].1 - bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ] . (76)

The inner product ukTâ¢oksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘œğ‘˜u_{k}^{T}o_{k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is proportional to the inner product between ekaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢xsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥e_{k}^{approx}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and eksubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

âŸ¨ekaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢x,ekâŸ©expectationsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜\displaystyle\braket{e_{k}^{approx},e_{k}}âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© =âˆ«(ukâ¢(X)Tâ¢Î¦â¢(x)skâ¢(X))Tâ¢okTâ¢Î¦â¢(x)Ïkâ¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xabsentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‡Î¦ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜ğ‘‹ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘œğ‘˜ğ‘‡Î¦ğ‘¥subscriptğœŒğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥\displaystyle=\int\left(\frac{u_{k}(X)^{T}\Phi(x)}{s_{k}(X)}\right)^{T}\frac{o% _{k}^{T}\Phi(x)}{\sqrt{\rho_{k}}}q(x)dx= âˆ« ( divide start_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (77)
=ukâ¢(X)Tskâ¢(X)â¢âˆ«Î¦â¢(x)Tâ¢Î¦â¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ¢okÏkabsentsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜ğ‘‹Î¦superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥subscriptğ‘œğ‘˜subscriptğœŒğ‘˜\displaystyle=\frac{u_{k}(X)^{T}}{s_{k}(X)}\int\Phi(x)^{T}\Phi(x)q(x)dx\frac{o% _{k}}{\sqrt{\rho_{k}}}= divide start_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) end_ARG âˆ« roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x divide start_ARG italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG (78)
=ukâ¢(X)Tskâ¢(X)â¢Dâ¢iâ¢aâ¢gâ¢(Ïk)â¢okÏkabsentsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜ğ‘‹ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘”subscriptğœŒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘œğ‘˜subscriptğœŒğ‘˜\displaystyle=\frac{u_{k}(X)^{T}}{s_{k}(X)}Diag(\rho_{k})\frac{o_{k}}{\sqrt{% \rho_{k}}}= divide start_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) end_ARG italic_D italic_i italic_a italic_g ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG (79)
=ukâ¢(X)Tâ¢okskâ¢(X)â¢Ïk,absentsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘œğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜ğ‘‹subscriptğœŒğ‘˜\displaystyle=\frac{u_{k}(X)^{T}o_{k}}{s_{k}(X)\sqrt{\rho_{k}}},= divide start_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) square-root start_ARG italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG , (80)

where the denominator is not of interest as we are not particularly interested in the norm of the ekaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢xsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥ğ‘˜e^{approx}_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

H.1.3 Results

In Figure 27 we generate a feature matrix containing n=10,000ğ‘›10000n=10,000italic_n = 10 , 000 datapoints and p=1000ğ‘1000p=1000italic_p = 1000 features with Gaussian random variables. We use the NystrÃ¶m method to approximate the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions and assess their accuracy with the metrics in Equation 75 and Equation 76. We observe in Figure 27(a) that eigenvalues are approximated precisely except for eigenvalues with kâ‰ˆpğ‘˜ğ‘k\approx pitalic_k â‰ˆ italic_p. In Figure 27(b), we observe that the accuracy of the eigenfunctions correlates with the respective eigenvalues: the larger the eigenvalue (compared to the median eigenvalue), the better the accuracy. In the main text, we are often interested only in the first few eigenfunctions with large eigenvalues; We can conclude that the NystrÃ¶m method is sufficiently accurate for our needs.

H.2 Function space approximation

The NystrÃ¶m methodâ€™s prediction accuracy degrades for smaller eigenvalues. The spanned space of [e1aâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢x,â‹¯,ekaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢x]superscriptsubscriptğ‘’1ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥â‹¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥[e_{1}^{approx},\cdots,e_{k}^{approx}][ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], however, often accurately approximates that of [e1,â‹¯,ek]subscriptğ‘’1â‹¯subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜[e_{1},\cdots,e_{k}][ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]; The larger error of the ekaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢xsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥e_{k}^{approx}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is often due to the cumulation of error in predicting ei<kaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢xsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥e_{i<k}^{approx}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i < italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Figure 28 illustrates an example where [u1,u2,u3]subscriptğ‘¢1subscriptğ‘¢2subscriptğ‘¢3[u_{1},u_{2},u_{3}][ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] span the same space as [o1,o2,o3]subscriptğ‘œ1subscriptğ‘œ2subscriptğ‘œ3[o_{1},o_{2},o_{3}][ italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], and u1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{1}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and u2subscriptğ‘¢2u_{2}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (thus e1subscriptğ‘’1e_{1}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and e2subscriptğ‘’2e_{2}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) are well approximated â€“ the errors in predicting u1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{1}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and u2subscriptğ‘¢2u_{2}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT accumulate to the error of predicting u3subscriptğ‘¢3u_{3}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and results in a poorer approximation for u3subscriptğ‘¢3u_{3}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We can use the Gaussian random variable setup to check the error of the function space approximation. To measure the similarity between sâ¢pâ¢aâ¢nâ¢([e1,â‹¯,ek])ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘’1â‹¯subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜span([e_{1},\cdots,e_{k}])italic_s italic_p italic_a italic_n ( [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) and approximated function space [e1aâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢x,â‹¯,ekaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢x]subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥1â‹¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥ğ‘˜[e^{approx}_{1},\cdots,e^{approx}_{k}][ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], we can use k-SVCCA [Raghu et al., 2017] or the cumulative projection measure in Equation 9.

1kâ¢âˆ‘i=1kâˆ‘j=1kâŸ¨ei|ejaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢xâŸ©2.1ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘˜superscriptinner-productsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥2\frac{1}{k}\sum_{i=1}^{k}\sum_{j=1}^{k}\braket{e_{i}}{e_{j}^{approx}}^{2}.divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_k end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (81)

Since we can express the inner product between true and approximated eigenfunctions with uksubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜u_{k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and oksubscriptğ‘œğ‘˜o_{k}italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Equation 77), we can express the metric in terms of uksubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜u_{k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and oksubscriptğ‘œğ‘˜o_{k}italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

1âˆ’1kâ¢âˆ‘i=1kâˆ‘j=1k(uiTâ¢oj)2,11ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘˜superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘œğ‘—21-\frac{1}{k}\sum_{i=1}^{k}\sum_{j=1}^{k}\left(u_{i}^{T}o_{j}\right)^{2},1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_k end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (82)

where we subtracted the measure from 1 so the measure will be 00 when there is no error. In Figure 27(c), we observe that the function space can be approximated more accurately in comparison to individual eigenfunctions in Figure 27(b); This is why we often present the quality and utility in cumulative measure Î âˆ—superscriptÎ \Pi^{*}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or Î ^^Î \hat{\Pi}over^ start_ARG roman_Î  end_ARG.

H.3 Error in projection measures

We now discuss the error in the projection measures like Î âˆ—superscriptÎ \Pi^{*}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The projection measure (Equation 7) consists of the sum of squares of inner products between eigenfunctions and function of interest (target or expressed). The Riemann sum over the test set approximates the inner product â€“ similar to how test loss approximates generalization loss.

âŸ¨ek,fjâŸ©2â€–ekâ€–22â¢â€–fjâ€–22=(âˆ«Ï‡ekâ¢(x)â¢fjâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘x)2âˆ«Ï‡ekâ¢(x)2â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ¢âˆ«Ï‡fjâ¢(x)2â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ‰ˆ(âˆ‘x(i)âˆˆStâ¢eekâ¢(x(i))â¢fjâ¢(x(i)))2âˆ‘x(i)âˆˆStâ¢eekâ¢(x(i))2â¢âˆ‘x(i)âˆˆStâ¢efjâ¢(x(i))2.superscriptexpectationsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—2subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜22subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—22superscriptsubscriptğœ’subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥2subscriptğœ’subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥subscriptğœ’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘’subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘’subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜superscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–2\frac{\braket{e_{k},f_{j}}^{2}}{\|e_{k}\|^{2}_{2}\|f_{j}\|^{2}_{2}}=\frac{%
