(83)

Using the Riemann sum, we can measure the correlation between spanned spaces (Equation 9). Using the vector representation of eigenfunction in the test set eiaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢xâ¢(Xtâ¢eâ¢sâ¢t)âˆˆâ„ntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡e^{approx}_{i}(X_{test})\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{test}}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the vector representation of function of interest fiâ¢(Xtâ¢eâ¢sâ¢t)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡f_{i}(X_{test})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we can approximate Equation 9 as

âˆ‘j=1Câˆ‘i=1pâŸ¨ei|fjâŸ©2â‰ˆTr(EFTFET),Eiâ¢j=eiaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢xâ¢(x(j))âˆ‘jnEiâ¢j2,Fiâ¢j=fiâ¢(x(j))âˆ‘jnFiâ¢j2.\sum_{j=1}^{C}\sum_{i=1}^{p}\braket{e_{i}}{f_{j}}^{2}\approx\mathrm{Tr}(EF^{T}% FE^{T})\quad\quad,E_{ij}=\frac{e^{approx}_{i}(x^{(j)})}{\sum_{j}^{n}E_{ij}^{2}% },\quad\ F_{ij}=\frac{f_{i}(x^{(j)})}{{\sum_{j}^{n}F_{ij}^{2}}}.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ roman_Tr ( italic_E italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (84)

where x(j)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x^{(j)}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are iterated over the test set. If the rows of Eâˆˆâ„pÃ—ntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tğ¸superscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡E\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times n_{test}}italic_E âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p Ã— italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Fâˆˆâ„CÃ—ntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tğ¹superscriptâ„ğ¶subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡F\in\mathbb{R}^{C\times n_{test}}italic_F âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C Ã— italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are orthogonal, then Equation 84 is smaller than equal to 1111: consistent with the definition of Equation 9.

However, Equation 84 is susceptible to error when: rows of Eğ¸Eitalic_E are not orthogonal and when pâ‰ˆntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡p\approx n_{test}italic_p â‰ˆ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We will discuss how we handled such problems in the paper.

H.3.1 Non orthogonal eigenfunctions

As discussed earlier, approximated eigenfunctions are less accurate when their eigenvalues are smaller; they may not even be orthogonal in qğ‘qitalic_q or the empirical distribution of the test set. The inner product between two approximated eigenfunctions is

âŸ¨eiaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢x|ejaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢xâŸ©inner-productsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥\displaystyle\braket{e_{i}^{approx}}{e_{j}^{approx}}âŸ¨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âŸ© =1siâ¢sjâ¢âˆ«Ï‡uiTâ¢Î¦â¢(x)â¢Î¦Tâ¢(x)â¢ujâ¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xabsent1subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—subscriptğœ’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘‡Î¦ğ‘¥superscriptÎ¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥\displaystyle=\frac{1}{s_{i}s_{j}}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}u_{i}^{T}\Phi(% x)\Phi^{T}(x)u_{j}q(x)dx= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (85)
=1siâ¢sjâ¢uiTâ¢(âˆ«Ï‡Î¦â¢(x)â¢Î¦Tâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘x)â¢ujabsent1subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğœ’Î¦ğ‘¥superscriptÎ¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—\displaystyle=\frac{1}{s_{i}s_{j}}u_{i}^{T}\left(\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0% .0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0% pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x)% \Phi^{T}(x)q(x)dx\right)u_{j}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x ) italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (86)
=1siâ¢sjâ¢uiTâ¢Jâ¢uj,absent1subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘‡ğ½subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—\displaystyle=\frac{1}{s_{i}s_{j}}u_{i}^{T}Ju_{j},= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (87)

where the Fisher information matrix Jâˆˆâ„pÃ—pğ½superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘J\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times p}italic_J âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p Ã— italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [Karakida et al., 2021] is defined as âˆ«Ï‡Î¦â¢(x)â¢Î¦Tâ¢(x)â¢qâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xsubscriptğœ’Î¦ğ‘¥superscriptÎ¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x)\Phi^{T}(x)q(x)dxâˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ ( italic_x ) roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x. Equation 85 equals Kronecker delta if only if [u1,â‹¯,up]subscriptğ‘¢1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘[u_{1},\cdots,u_{p}][ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] are the eigenvectors of Jğ½Jitalic_J with eigenvalues [s12,â‹¯,sp2]superscriptsubscriptğ‘ 12â‹¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘2[s_{1}^{2},\cdots,s_{p}^{2}][ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]. Since we obtained uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the empirical feature matrix of the training set, the approximated eigenfunctions, especially those with small eigenvalues, are often not orthogonal in qğ‘qitalic_q (and in the test set).

To handle such an issue, we use QR decomposition on E=[e1aâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢xâ¢(Xtâ¢eâ¢sâ¢t),â‹¯,epaâ¢pâ¢pâ¢râ¢oâ¢xâ¢(Xtâ¢eâ¢sâ¢t)]âˆˆâ„pÃ—ntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tğ¸subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡E=[e^{approx}_{1}(X_{test}),\cdots,e^{approx}_{p}(X_{test})]\in\mathbb{R}^{p% \times n_{test}}italic_E = [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , â‹¯ , italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p Ã— italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT before applying Equation 84: because QR decomposition orthogonalizes the rows; preserves the span of the first kğ‘˜kitalic_k vectors; handles overlapping vector between rows by conserving larger eigenvalue eigenvectors (eigenfunctions) - which are more accurate.

In Figure 29, we plot the cumulative measure with and without QR decomposition for ResNet18 on CIFAR10. We observe that Î âˆ—superscriptÎ \Pi^{*}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Î ^^Î \hat{\Pi}over^ start_ARG roman_Î  end_ARG grow beyond 1111 without QR decomposition, indicating that approximated eigenfunctions are not orthogonal; The inconsistent behaviour is removed when QR decomposition is applied. Note that the deviation between QR and no-QR plots emerges when the eigenvalues are sufficiently small (larger error in approximating the eigenfunction).

H.3.2 Finite size effect

For two sets of basis functions, increasing the number of bases to a large but finite value does not guarantee any overlap between the two function spaces: because functions are infinite-dimensional vectors. This is not the case for two finite-dimensional matrices: If p=ntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡p=n_{test}italic_p = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation 84 and Eğ¸Eitalic_E has full rank, then any Fğ¹Fitalic_F will be spanned by the rows of Eğ¸Eitalic_E.

In Figure 29(a,b), we observe that Î âˆ—â¢(ntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢t)superscriptÎ subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\Pi^{*}(n_{test})roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and Î ^â¢(ntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢t)^Î subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\hat{\Pi}(n_{test})over^ start_ARG roman_Î  end_ARG ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are equal to 1111 for layers with p>ntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡p>n_{test}italic_p > italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This does not indicate that intermediate features can express the target/expressed function; It is achieved because ntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡n_{test}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT orthogonal vectors (Eğ¸Eitalic_E) can always span ntâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡n_{test}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT dimensional vector space (and thus the row space of Fğ¹Fitalic_F).

Report Github Issue
Generated by L A T E xml

Instructions for reporting errors

We are continuing to improve HTML versions of papers, and your feedback helps enhance accessibility and mobile support. To report errors in the HTML that will help us improve conversion and rendering, choose any of the methods listed below:

  • Click the "Report Issue" button.
  • Open a report feedback form via keyboard, use "Ctrl + ?".
  • Make a text selection and click the "Report Issue for Selection" button near your cursor.
  • You can use Alt+Y to toggle on and Alt+Shift+Y to toggle off accessible reporting links at each section.

Our team has already identified the following issues. We appreciate your time reviewing and reporting rendering errors we may not have found yet. Your efforts will help us improve the HTML versions for all readers, because disability should not be a barrier to accessing research. Thank you for your continued support in championing open access for all.

Have a free development cycle? Help support accessibility at arXiv! Our collaborators at LaTeXML maintain a list of packages that need conversion, and welcome developer contributions.
